questions.question: What was Philip V's primary strategic calculation when he allied with Hannibal?
options: He wanted to defeat Rome militarily for Alexander's legacy
If Rome was distracted fighting Hannibal, Rome would be vulnerable to Macedonian expansion in the east
He believed Carthage and Macedonia could jointly conquer the Mediterranean
He wanted to protect Greek city-states from Roman conquest
He was pressured into the alliance by other Hellenistic powers

questions.question: How did Carthage's economic recovery after the Second War create strategic problems for Rome?
options: Carthage's prosperity threatened Rome's commercial dominance directly
Rome feared a recovered Carthage might eventually rebuild military strength and threaten Rome again
Carthage's wealth allowed it to pay off Masinissa and end harassment
Carthaginian merchants began trading with Rome's enemies
Economic recovery somehow violated the treaty terms

questions.question: Which of the following were true about Flamininus as a Roman commander? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: He ordered the complete destruction of Macedonian cities
He was relatively young for such an important military command
He studied Greek language and culture
He was known for both military skill and diplomatic ability
He was celebrated in Greece as a hero after Cynoscephalae
He refused to engage with Greek city-states politically
questions.text_reference: Section 3 - Roman Leadership: Titus Quinctius Flamininus

questions.question: How did the Treaty of 196 BCE regarding Greece differ from typical Roman territorial conquest?
options: Greece was completely incorporated as a Roman province with governors
Greek city-states were declared 'free and independent' but were effectively under Roman dominance
Rome granted complete autonomy to all Greek territories
Greece remained under Macedonian rule with Roman supervision
Rome limited its involvement to strategic coastal cities only

questions.question: What was the relationship between Carthage's attempts to defend itself against Masinissa and Rome's declaration of war? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: When Carthage militarily responded to Masinissa, it violated the treaty prohibition against war without Roman approval
Carthage had the right to defend itself regardless of treaty restrictions
Rome forced Carthage to make the military response to trap them
Masinissa was actually an independent actor with no connection to Rome's war decision
Rome saw an opportunity to use treaty violations as a pretext for war
questions.text_reference: Section 7 - Carthage's Violation of the Treaty

questions.question: How did Cato the Elder shift Roman public opinion regarding Carthage?
options: He provided rational and compelling economic arguments that successfully convinced Roman merchants and business interests
He invoked Hannibal's trauma, argued about strategic threat, commercial competition, and repeatedly used 'Carthago delenda est'
He demonstrated through detailed evidence that Carthage was actively and aggressively rebuilding its military forces and naval power
He personally led military campaigns against Carthaginian territories that proved Carthage remained a significant military threat
He was supported unanimously by the entire Roman Senate from the very beginning of his political campaign

questions.question: Which of the following factors contributed to Rome's decision to completely destroy rather than merely conquer Carthage? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Political consensus built by Cato and the anti-Carthage faction
Religious beliefs that Carthage was cursed by the gods
Psychological fear stemming from Hannibal's invasion during the Second War
Direct orders from Alexander's descendant
Strategic calculation that an independent Carthage was more dangerous than elimination
Economic interests in eliminating a commercial competitor

questions.question: What did the Third Macedonian War (171-168 BCE) demonstrate about Roman power?
options: Macedonia had secretly regained military strength equal to Rome's
Rome was no longer militarily superior to Hellenistic powers
Rome's military dominance was complete and lasting—Macedonia could not challenge Rome even after 30 years
Macedonian phalanx tactics had improved dramatically since Cynoscephalae
Rome was becoming weaker and needed to consolidate power

questions.question: How did Rome's expansion into the Mediterranean create new administrative and political challenges? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome had to develop systems for administering vast diverse territories
Commanders of distant armies gained power and ambition
Rome's military became too large to control
Conquered peoples welcomed Roman rule universally
Competition for control of lucrative provinces created internal tensions
Rome's Senate lost all political power to military commanders

questions.question: What was ironic about Rome's strategy of using Masinissa to weaken Carthage?
options: Masinissa eventually became stronger than Rome and posed his own threat
It worked too well—Carthage was already weakened when Rome finally attacked
Carthage was driven to desperate military action that violated the treaty, providing Rome's war justification
It prevented Rome from directly controlling Numidian territories
Masinissa refused to attack Carthage if Rome didn't order him directly
